io.spine.server.entity.storage

Class EntityColumn

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.spine.server.entity.storage.EntityColumn
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    @Immutable
 @Experimental
public final class EntityColumn
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    An Entity field stored in a way allowing ordering and filtering.

    The value stored in an entity column is retrieved from an Entity getter method marked with Column annotation.

    An entity can inherit the columns from its parent classes and interfaces. In this case column getter is annotated only once when it is first declared.

    The name of a column is determined by the Column.name() annotation property. If the property is not defined, the name is extracted from the column getter method, for example, value for getValue().

    Examples

    These methods represent the columns: 

          

         --OrderAggregate.java--

         \@Column
         public boolean isDuplicate() {
             return getState().isDuplicate();
         }

         --UserGroupAggregate.java--

         \@Column
         public int getUserCount() {
             return getState().getUserCount();
         }

         --PaymentProcessManager.java--

         \@Nullable
         \@Column
         public Date getPaymentSystemName() {
             if (getState().hasExpirationDate()) {
                 return new Date();
             } else {
                 return null;
             }
         }

    And these methods are not considered to represent columns: 

          
         --UserAggregate.java--

         // only methods annotated with @Column can be considered Columns
         public Department getDepartment() { ... }

         // non-public methods cannot represent Columns
         \@Column
         private double getHourRate() { ... }

         // only methods starting with "get" or "is" can be considered Columns
         \@Column
         public boolean hasChildren() { ... }

         // "is" prefix is allowed only for methods which return "boolean" or "Boolean"
         \@Column
         public int isNew() { ... }

         // getter methods must not accept arguments
         \@Column
         public User getStateOf(UserAggregate other) { ... }

         // only instance methods are considered Columns
         \@Column
         public static boolean isDeleted(UserAggregate aggregate) { ... }

    Type policy

    An entity column can be of any type. Most common types are already supported if an existing implementation of the Spine Storage is used. However, their behavior can be overridden using ColumnTypeRegistry.

    To handle column types not supported by default implement the ColumnType interface, register it in a ColumnTypeRegistry and pass the instance of the registry into the StorageFactory upon creation.

    Note that the column type must either be a primitive or implement Serializable. To order the query results on a column value, it is also required to implement Comparable.

    Nullability

    A column may contain null value if the getter which declares it is marked as nullable. More formally, if the getter method is annotated with an annotation the simple name of which is CheckForNull, Nullable, NullableDecl, or NullableType, the column may be null. Otherwise, the entity column is considered non-null.

    If a non-null getter method returns null when trying to get the value of a column, a RuntimeException is thrown. See EntityColumn.isNullable().

    The example below shows a faulty column which will throw RuntimeException when trying to get its value. 

         
         --EmployeeProjection.java--

         // method should be annotated as @Nullable to return a null value
         \@Column
         public Message getAddress() {
             return null;
         }
    See Also:
    ColumnType, Serialized Form

    • Method Detail

      • from

        public static EntityColumn from(java.lang.reflect.Method getter)
        Creates a new instance of the EntityColumn from the given getter method.

        The given method must be annotated with the Column annotation. An IllegalArgumentException is thrown otherwise.

        Parameters:
        getter - the getter of the EntityColumn
        Returns:
        new instance of the EntityColumn reflecting the given property

      • name

        public java.lang.String name()
        Obtains the name of the column which is used for querying.

        For example, if the getter method has name "isArchivedOrDeleted", the returned value is "archivedOrDeleted".

        Returns:
        the column name for querying

      • isNullable

        public boolean isNullable()
        Determines whether the column value may be null.
        Returns:
        true if the getter method is annotated as Nullable, false otherwise

      • valueIn

        public @Nullable java.io.Serializable valueIn(Entity<?,?> source)
        Retrieves the column value from the given Entity.
        Parameters:
        source - the Entity to get the Columns from
        Returns:
        the value of the column represented by this instance

      • type

        public java.lang.Class type()
        Obtains the type of the column.

      • persistedType

        public java.lang.Class persistedType()
        Returns the type under which the column values are persisted in the data storage.

        For the non-Enumerated entity columns this type will be equal to the one retrieved using the EntityColumn.type().

        For the Enumerated columns, see EnumConverter implementations.

        Returns:
        the persistence type of the column values

      • toPersistedValue

        public @Nullable java.io.Serializable toPersistedValue(@Nullable java.lang.Object columnValue)
        Converts the column value into the value for persistence in the data storage.

        This method can be used to transform the value obtained through the EntityColumn getter into the corresponding value used for persistence in the data storage.

        The value type should be the same as the one obtained through the EntityColumn.type(). The output value type will be the same as EntityColumn.persistedType().

        As the column value may be nullable, and all null values are persisted in the data storage as null, for example, without any conversion. For the null input argument this method will always return null.

        The method is accessible outside of the EntityColumn class to enable the proper filters conversion for the Enumerated column values.

        Parameters:
        columnValue - the column value to convert
        Returns:
        the column value converted to the form used for persistence in the data storage
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the value type is not equal to the entity column type
